{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13562,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rosa multiflora, commonly known as multiflora rose, prefers well-drained soil with consistent moisture. Water the plant deeply and thoroughly, especially during dry spells or in the heat of summer. Allow the soil to dry slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. Depending on the weather and soil type, watering once or twice a week may be sufficient. Always water at the base of the plant to keep the foliage dry and minimize the risk of fungal diseases. Utilize mulch to help retain soil moisture and maintain even soil temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rosa multiflora thrives in full sun, ideally receiving at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily. This level of sunlight encourages robust flower production and healthy, vigorous growth. In regions with extremely hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from intense sun and heat. However, insufficient sunlight can lead to fewer blooms and leggy growth, so it's important to plant it in a location where it can bask in ample sunlight. Ensure that nearby trees or structures do not cast excessive shade over the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rosa multiflora is essential for promoting healthy growth and preventing it from becoming invasive. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, diseased, or crossing branches to open up the center of the plant and improve air circulation. Cut back the canes to a healthy bud to encourage new flowering shoots. Regular pruning helps maintain its shape and prevents it from overrunning other plants or structures. During the growing season, deadhead spent flowers to prolong blooming and reduce seed spread."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"multiflora rose","description":"Rosa multiflora (syn. Rosa polyantha) is a species of rose known commonly as multiflora rose, baby rose, Japanese rose, many-flowered rose, seven-sisters rose, and Eijitsu rose. It is native to eastern Asia, in China, Japan and Korea. It should not be confused with Rosa rugosa, which is also known as \"Japanese rose\", or with polyantha roses which are garden cultivars derived from hybrids of R. multiflora.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Eastern Asia"],"other_name":["multiflora rose"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Rose slug sawfly","Black spot","Powdery mildew","Japanese beetle"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Rosa multiflora"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Remove dead or damaged stems and spent flowers to encourage new growth and maintain the plant's appearance. Late winter or early spring is ideal for any necessary pruning. Ensure that pruning tools are clean to prevent the spread of disease. Regular deadheading can also promote prolonged blooming."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mojave Woodyaster","description":"Xylorhiza tortifolia is a species of flowering plant in the aster family, known by the common names Mojave-aster and Mojave woodyaster.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Mojave Woodyaster"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Xylorhiza tortifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In winter, when the plant is dormant, water even less frequently, as the plant needs just enough moisture to prevent desiccation but not enough to stimulate new growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The Diamond Cholla thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. If grown indoors, place the plant in a south or west-facing window where it can receive the maximum amount of direct light. Adjust positioning as needed to prevent shading from nearby structures or plants."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning the Diamond Cholla is not often necessary, but it can help maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. Remove any dead or diseased stems using clean, sharp pruners. Wear protective gloves and long sleeves to avoid contact with the spines. Prune in the early spring if you want to control the plant's size and promote new branching. Always cut above a node to stimulate growth at the cut point. Throughout the year, remove any stems that are damaged or interfere with a desired aesthetic or spatial requirement in your garden."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Branched Pencil Cholla","description":"Cylindropuntia ramosissima is a species of cactus known by the common names diamond cholla and branched pencil cholla.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["Branched Pencil Cholla"],"pest_susceptibility":["Scale insects"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Cylindropuntia ramosissima"],"soil":["Rocky","Gravelly","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the plant's dormancy or late in fall, consider a light trim to maintain the desired size. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12771,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Bituminaria bituminosa is relatively drought-tolerant once established, so it doesn’t require frequent watering. Ideally, water this plant only when the top inch of the soil feels dry to the touch. During hot, dry spells or in warm climates, the plant might need more frequent watering to maintain its health. In contrast, reduce watering during the winter months when the plant's growth slows down. Ensure good drainage as the plant does not tolerate waterlogging well, which can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Bituminaria bituminosa thrives in full sunlight, so it should be placed in a location that receives at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day. It can also tolerate partial shade, but its growth might be less robust compared to full sun exposure. When grown indoors, place the plant near a south-facing window where it can receive the most light. In regions with extremely hot summers, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent scorching."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Bituminaria bituminosa should be done minimally, as they maintain a natural shape without much interference. If needed, prune in early spring to remove any dead or damaged growth and encourage new growth. Pruning may also help promote bushier growth and manage the plant's size. Always use clean, sharp tools to avoid disease transmission and make sure to cut just above a leaf node or bud to encourage healthy regrowth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"arabian pea","description":"Bituminaria bituminosa, the Arabian pea or pitch trefoil, is a perennial Mediterranean herb species in the genus Bituminaria.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean"],"other_name":["arabian pea"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Bituminaria bituminosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Water this plant sparingly, ensuring that the soil completely dries out between waterings to prevent root rot. It is important to reduce water frequency during the winter months when the plant's growth slows down. Always ensure that the plant has good drainage, as waterlogging can be detrimental. A good practice is to water deeply but infrequently, letting the top couple of inches of soil dry out between sessions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Stillingia spinulosa requires a substantial amount of sunlight to thrive and perform optimal photosynthesis. It prefers full sun to partial shade, with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In regions with intense midday sun, some light shading can prevent leaf scorching. If grown indoors, place it near a south-facing window where it can receive plenty of natural light, or supplement with grow lights if natural light is insufficient. Adequate sunlight helps maintain the plant's robust shape and encourages vibrant growth patterns."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Stillingia spinulosa should be carried out to maintain its size and shape and to encourage healthier growth. The best time to prune is late winter or early spring, right before the growing season starts. Trim back any dead or diseased stems to prevent the spread of disease. Additionally, remove any crossing branches or those that grow inward to enhance air circulation. Always use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts and prevent damage to the plant tissue. Regular light pruning will help maintain its structural integrity and vigor."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Annual Toothleaf","description":"Stillingia spinulosa is a species of flowering plant in the euphorb family known by the common name annual toothleaf. It is native to the southwestern United States where it occurs in the creosote scrub of the deserts. It is an annual or perennial herb producing a clump of thick, leafy stems approaching a meter in maximum height. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":13071,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Erodium texanum, commonly known as Texas stork's bill, is a drought-tolerant species that prefers dry conditions. Water the plant sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out completely between watering sessions. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it is crucial to ensure that the plant is not sitting in moist soil for prolonged periods. In the cooler months, reduce watering even further as the plant enters a period of dormancy. When watering, aim to water deeply but infrequently to encourage strong root growth and drought resistance."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Erodium texanum thrives in full sunlight and performs best when exposed to at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. This plant is native to desert regions and is well adapted to intense sunlight and heat. If grown in shadier conditions, it may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Therefore, placing it in a south-facing position if outdoors, or near a bright, sunny window if indoors, is recommended. Ensure the plant is not overshadowed by taller plants or structures to maintain its health and vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Erodium texanum typically involves minimal intervention, as the plant naturally maintains a compact growth habit. However, occasional pruning can help maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. Remove any dead or damaged leaves and spent flowers regularly to keep the plant looking tidy and to prevent any potential pest or disease problems. If the plant becomes too leggy or overgrown, trim it back lightly to foster compact growth. Do this after the flowering period to avoid cutting off any developing buds."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Texas stork's bill","description":"Erodium texanum, also known as Texas filaree, Texas stork's bill, or heronbill, is a flowering plant which is native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is an annual or biennial herb.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Texas stork's bill"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Erodium texanum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
